content: I'm finally doing a Backdrop rebuild of a big Drupal 7 site that uses Biblio. IIRC @jenlampton made a Backdrop version that was a major improvement, but it looks like it's not available as a module? Is there any chance the code is available someplace?

Hi, Quinn Dombrowski. Welcome to the Backdrop CMS community on Zulip. I'm your friendly neighborhood Dragonbot. Try '@Dragonbot help' for a list of things I can help you with. There are lots of friendly humans that hang around here, so please feel free to ask questions.

Here is a short (3 min) video to help you navigate Zulip. https://youtu.be/DN8YL2MrsSU

Hi @Quinn Dombrowski, it seems that biblio for Backdrop has no stable release yet. Possibly the port is still ongoing? https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/biblio
It could be helpful to open an Issue in the module's Issue queue. Maybe you can help out with some testing...

backdrop-contrib/biblio
Manage and display lists of scholarly publications. Import from Zotero. - backdrop-contrib/biblio
Great, thank you! Will do; happy to be a tester on this.
Hi @Quinn Dombrowski ! Yes, I have a version. should be in contrib... checking...

Ah yes, here we go: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/biblio

backdrop-contrib/biblio
Manage and display lists of scholarly publications. Import from Zotero. - backdrop-contrib/biblio
No official release yet. Can you give it a test, and if it works okay I'll make a release :)

@Quinn Dombrowski it should work nearly the same as it did in Drupal 6, but with a Drupal7 / Backdrop style architecture using nodes, and terms instead of the custom drupal-6 style data storage. There is an upgrade path from that old data architecture, but since I was working on a Drupal 6 upgrade, I wasn't sure the upgrade path would be the same from Drupal 7. If you aren't upgrading, everything should work perfectly! (famous last words...)
As you work, if you have questions feel free to ask here. If I don't respond you can throw the Qs in the queue and I'll get to them when I'm back at the computer :)
Thanks! I just installed it. (Also discovered Multifield in the process and am super excited about it in hopes of getting rid of those stupid D7 field collections!)
@Quinn Dombrowski I'm personally a big fan of multifield, but I think most people are moving to Paragraphs.
Blast. I've never really loved paragraphs. Do you figure it's better to go with it for longer-term sustainability?

Biblio appears to be dependent on multifield.

I'm curious what you don't like about paragraphs @Quinn Dombrowski ?
I‘m also interested in Biblio. Is it working for you, @Quinn Dombrowski ?
@Olaf Grabienski all the "Publications" on this site are brought in via biblio + zotero http://arf.berkeley.edu/home

@Laryn I might be missing something, but all the documentation and explanation I've seen of Paragraphs feels oriented towards different types of display vs. fundamentally storing different types of data. Display isn't really a huge concern for my projects; I just want the old school "multigroup" that never quite stuck (e.g. for if you want to gather together names of people who worked on a book, and be able to write a name + choose a role like author or illustrator from a dropdown).
I might need to try this module out tomorrow. I could probably find some way to use it on a library site. Does it work with MARC records like the Drupal version?
@Justin Keiser right now the only importer that exists is for Zotero, but since it uses Feeds module, any standard data feed can be easily ingested.

The advantage of paragraphs over multifield is that you can mix and match paragraph types, and that content editors can reorder them. With multifields you don't get that much flexibility, as what types of subfields are included in each multifield is specific with each "instance" or "item".
And you can nest paragraphs and other entities within paragraphs within paragraphs ad nauseam until you have a site that barely functions due to bloat.
Why do people like multifield more than field collections?

@Quinn Dombrowski I would think Paragraphs could handle that pretty easily, but if Multifields is enough for you and feels better it should be fine, too. I have only used Multifields briefly and then switched to Paragraphs. IIRC part of the issue for me was that Multifields couldn't be adjusted at all once you had data in there (e.g. adding a new field to an existing multifield).

@Herb I prefer multifield because it does not make your site slow :) All the field data is stored in the field table for the multifield, not other field tables that need to be joined to, so it makes queries much faster, especially when you have lots of data in them.

Most of the time my sites aren't page-builder stye sites where a single page is made up of rows of different paragraph content stacked up (the use-case for paragraphs). Mine are usually simpler "article aggregators" where they have a single node type with a repeating pattern. here's a good example of a "Listicle" https://www.animationcareerreview.com/articles/top-50-animation-schools-and-colleges-us-2020-college-rankings

Top 50 Animation Schools and Colleges in the U.S. – 2020 College Rankings
Our 2020 list of the Top 50 Animation School Programs in the US. For an explanation of ranking criteria, click here.
Here each multifleld is an image, an (optional) link, a heading, and a chunk of text.
